thread.title: Undefeated transgender wrestler wins girls championship but sparks controversy with use of testosterone - Mirror Online
thread.title_full: Undefeated transgender wrestler wins girls championship but sparks controversy with use of testosterone - Mirror Online

author: Ross Logan
title: Undefeated transgender wrestler wins girls championship but sparks controversy with use of testosterone - Mirror Online
text:
News Undefeated transgender wrestler wins girls championship but sparks controversy with use of testosterone Debate is raging over whether Mack Begg should be allowed to compete with girls while taking testosterone during his transition Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Transgender wrestler breezes through all-female tournament Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A transgender high school wrestler has won a girls' championship title amid huge controversy in Texas. 
Mack Beggs, 17, won the Class 6A 110-pound girls' division on Saturday night amid calls from some parents, coaches and fans for him to be disqualified. 
The teenager, of Trinity High School's Euless Trinity team, was born female but is transitioning to a man, requiring testosterone treatment. 
Although testosterone is a banned substance, Mack is allowed to take it because it is for "valid medical use". 
It is the state's athletic policy for students to compete against the gender assigned on their birth certificate. Read More Mack Beggs is on a 55 match winning streak (Photo: Reuters) Mack Beggs won the 110 pound girls' state championship on Saturday (Photo: CBSDFW/Youtube) 
Last night he comprehensively beat Chelsea Sanchez of Morton Ranch 12-2 to claim the title. 
The victory takes his win/loss record to 55-0. 
Mack's inclusion in the Euless Trinity girls' team has dominated the competition all week. 
Until last night, the wrestler had tried to avoid the media circus surrounding him, dodging photographers by appearing out of different tunnels, and running out of the ring immediately after his victories. 
But after winning his title, he spoke publicly for the first time. 
"I wouldn't be here today if it weren't for my teammates," he said, according to Dallas Morning News . But some say it is unfair that he can only wrestle girls because he was born female (Photo: Facebook) Beggs' title win raises more questions of Texas' sports regulations policy on birth gender (Photo: CBSDFW/Youtube) 
"That's honestly what the spotlight should've been on, my teammates. 
"The hard work that I put in the practice room with them beside me, we trained hard every single day. 
"That's what the spotlight should've been on." Read More 
On Friday mack had defeated Taylor Latham and Mya Engert in the Class 6A girls 110-pound weight class by 18 points to 7 and 12-4 respectively. 
One mother was reportedly heard calling Mack a 'big cheater' as he left the ring. 
Taylor Latham's mother Lisa said she had wanted her daughter to forfeit the match "as a protective mom". One parent was heard calling Mack a "big cheater' (Photo: Facebook) Mack was booed by a small minority of the audience during his last victory (Photo: Facebook) 
"But she's a fighter. She's not a quitter," she said. 
"Mack wants to wrestle boys and he'll never be recognized as a boy because of the birth certificate in the state of Texas." 
The birth certificate policy was passed by the University Interscholastic League (UIL) last August, with 95 per cent of the vote. Read More 
Given the near unanimous support for the policy, UIL deputy director Jamey Harrison told reporters it was unlikley to change anytime soon. Mack Beggs says only parents and coaches have a problem with him wrestling girls (Photo: Facebook) The 17-year-old is permitted to wrestle while undergo testosterone therapy because it is a 'valid medical use' (Photo: Facebook) 
Mack himself has previously hit back at his critics, saying only parents and coaches have a problem with him wrestling girls. 
Writing on Facebook, the teenager said he was "sick and disgusted by the discrimination of the adults. 
"These kids don't care who you put in front of them to wrestle," he said. "We just want to WRESTLE. 
"THEY are taking that away from me and from the people I'm competing with." Like us on Facebook
